Emilio Estevez was born on May 12, 1962, in Staten Island, New York, to actor Martin Sheen and artist Janet Templeton. He is the oldest of four children, including actors Charlie Sheen, Ramón Estevez, and Renée Estevez.

Estevez began his acting career in the late 1970s, appearing in several television shows and films, including "Apocalypse Now" (1979) and "The Outsiders" (1983). He gained recognition for his roles in the Brat Pack films "The Breakfast Club" (1985), "St. Elmo's Fire" (1985), and "Young Guns" (1988).

In addition to his acting career, Estevez has also ventured into directing and writing. He made his directorial debut with the film "Bobby" (2006), a drama about the life and death of Senator Robert F. Kennedy. He has also directed several other films, including "The Public" (2018), a drama about a group of homeless individuals who take shelter in a public library.

Estevez has been married to his wife, Sonja Magdevski, since 2006, and they have two children together. He is known for his dedication to his craft and his philanthropic work, particularly in the area of youth development and education.

Throughout his career, Estevez has received numerous awards and nominations for his work, including a Golden Globe nomination for his performance in "Bobby." He continues to be an active and respected figure in the film industry, with a career spanning over four decades.
